nodes.text: Human information processing has a limited capacity that often appears near seven items or categories in many tasks (the 'magical number seven'), reflecting constraints on absolute judgment and immediate memory
Information theory concepts map psychological variance to bits and transmitted information to input-output covariance, providing a quantitative framework for measuring perceptual channel capacity

Absolute judgment experiments treat the observer as a communication channel: input information is stimulus variance, output information is response variance, overlap is transmitted information, and the asymptotic transmitted information is the observer's channel capacity

For unidimensional stimuli measured across multiple studies, measured channel capacities cluster in a narrow range with mean about 2.6 bits (approx 6.5 distinguishable categories) and standard deviation about 0.6 bit
Pitch absolute-judgment experiments (Pollack) show transmitted information rising with input bits then asymptoting near 2.5 bits, implying about six reliably discriminable pitches

Loudness (Garner) yields channel capacity about 2.3 bits (~5 alternatives) and taste concentrations (Beebe-Center et al.) yield about 1.9 bits (~4 alternatives), showing similar order of magnitude across sensory modalities

Visual position and other visual measures show larger unidimensional capacities (position in interval ~3.25 bits; some visual metrics up to 3.9 bits), giving an empirical range roughly from 1.6 to 3.9 bits depending on variable and conditions

Adding independently variable stimulus dimensions increases total channel capacity but with diminishing returns; capacities for multidimensional stimuli are greater than for single dimensions but less than the sum of independent capacities

Two-dimensional judgments e.g. dot position in square (Klemmer and Frick) show channel capacity 4.6 bits (about 24 positions), which is greater than one-dimensional position but less than the simple sum of two independent interval judgments

High-dimensional auditory experiments (Pollack and Ficks) with six independent dimensions produced transmitted information around 7.2 bits (about 150 categories), showing multidimensional and binary-feature strategies can greatly expand identifiable categories
Immediate memory span experiments show span is constrained by number of chunks (about seven chunks) rather than constant total bits; span remains near seven across items with differing bits per item

Empirical evidence: Hayes and Pollack measured spans for binary digits, decimal digits, letters, and words and found span variations inconsistent with a constant-bits hypothesis and consistent with a roughly constant chunk count

Recoding (grouping input into larger chunks or renaming groups) increases bits per chunk and thus expands immediate memory capacity dramatically when practiced until automatic, as shown in Smith's binary-to-octal recoding experiments

Evidence for recoding: Smith and self-experiments show that with practiced recoding from binary to octal or larger bases a person can recall many more binary digits (e.g., up to about 40) because chunks carry more bits

Conclusions: Distinguish bits versus chunks as different limiting resources (absolute judgment limited by bits per channel, immediate memory limited by chunk count); recoding and increasing dimensionality are practical strategies humans use to overcome bottlenecks; information theory offers useful quantitative tools

Limitations and open questions: exceptional abilities (e.g., absolute pitch), possible upper bounds on perceptual dimensionality (speculated near ten), and whether language production or perception constrains speech feature dimensionality remain unresolved
